article.description:
Rashard Lewis scored 23 points and Desmond Mason
added 20 points in a rare starting appearance, leading the Seattle
SuperSonics to a 90-77 win over the Chicago Bulls on Saturday
night.
article.headline: Mason scores 20 in ninth start of the year
article.linkText: Mason shines in rare start for Sonics
article.story:
SEATTLE (AP) -- Nate McMillan wanted to see more second-half energy from the Seattle SuperSonics. Desmond Mason and Reggie Evans delivered. Rashard Lewis scored 23 points and Mason added 20 in a rare starting appearance, leading the Seattle SuperSonics to a 90-77 win over the Chicago Bulls on Saturday night. Gary Payton had 20 points and eight assists for Seattle, which has won three of its last four. "I challenged them at halftime to come out aggressive on defense and put the game away," McMillan said. "Even though we played well in the first half, I thought we could have played better." The Sonics have promoted Mason for the league's Sixth Man award this season. But he looked quite comfortable in his ninth start, shooting 7-of-12 and collecting eight rebounds. "I just wanted to be more aggressive," Mason said. "I tried to do that by moving more toward the basket." Evans grabbed 12 rebounds and the Sonics had a 51-40 advantage on the boards. "That's part of my role," said Evans, who had five offensive rebounds. "I just have to do the best that I can to get second opportunities." Jalen Rose scored 23 points while Donyell Marshall added 14 and Jamal Crawford 12 for Chicago, which fell to an NBA-worst 2-23 on the road. "I told my guys that until we decide that we're going to guard somebody and then come down and execute our offense, this is going to continue to happen," Bulls coach Bill Cartwright said. The Bulls proved to be the perfect medicine for a Seattle team that has struggled to find much second-half offense over the past few weeks. The Sonics will be tested again on next week's trip to New Jersey, Boston and Milwaukee. "We have to get better to beat some of these teams that we'll face out on the road this week," McMillan said. "Our goal is to try and reach .500 by the All-Star break and we need all three of these games." The Sonics (21-24) outscored the Bulls 25-12 in the third quarter, and the outcome was decided by the time Lewis completed a three-point play for a 70-52 lead with 34.2 seconds remaining in the third. Seattle began the second half energized, using a 14-2 run to extend a 45-42 halftime lead. It was a marked contrast from two nights earlier, when Seattle went flat in the third quarter of a loss to Sacramento. "I thought the guys did a good job of moving the ball," McMillan said. "There was better movement on the weak side." Payton scored nine points and Lewis had seven in the third period. The Sonics were effective at getting the ball inside, and they hit 11-of-13 from the free-throw line to build a 70-54 lead going into the fourth quarter. "Much respect to the Sonics," Rose said. "They came out and played hard. When we made mistakes and missed shots, they found ways to capitalize." One night after losing 107-94 in Portland, the Bulls lost their third straight on a five-game road trip. They were sluggish in the third quarter, a step slow on defense as Seattle methodically took control with free throws. Game notes
With the Sonics leading 77-60, McMillan was whistled for a fourth-quarter technical after Marshall got away with an offensive foul. ... The Sonics used their 13th lineup this season. ... Before tipoff, the Bulls placed F Marcus Fizer on the injured list with a sprained right knee and activated C Dalibor Bagaric. ... Sonics G Brent Barry missed his fourth straight game because of left knee tendinitis. ... Bulls G Jay Williams went scoreless on 0-for-5 shooting in 20 minutes, his second game after a five-game absence with a sprained left ankle.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
